Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: An online experiential learning platform to instruct participants on the leading practices for innovation
Award.AbstractNarration:
This SBIR Phase I project's broader/commercial impact includes the ability for individuals or organizations, across all geographies, industries and sectors, to benefit from an educational platform that helps them better understand which set of practices, consistently applied, can lead to breakthrough innovations. The ability to successfully innovate is critical. Whether one is looking to develop a new social media platform in Silicon Valley or eradicate disease in a 3rd world country, the leading practices of innovation can serve as a series of guideposts to answer critical questions. These critical questions include; How to determine where to invest limited human and capital resources' How to properly balance high risk/ high reward innovation pursuits with incremental improvements which carry less risk? How to determine criteria that will be used to determine which ideas to pursue and which to pivot away from?. Once the cloud-based version of this product is fully commercialized, it will allow participants to "move the dial" in order to simulate (and eventually overcome) cultural impediments that are preventing meaningful innovation within their organizations.

This SBIR Phase I project intends to prove that an experiential learning method is superior to traditional forms of instruction for communicating the leading practices of innovation. To date, leading practices for innovation have been conveyed using traditional forms of instruction such as lecture, case study, and white papers. While experiential forms of instruction have proven useful in many areas of study including accounting, international business and strategy, they have not been use to convey innovation's leading practices. The proposed research will demonstrate that a well-designed experiential game, academically anchored and drawing from existing literature focusing on innovation, will provide participants a richer educational experience resulting in greater learning and retention.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objective of our Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project was to demonstrate that an experiential learning method is superior to traditional lecture instruction for communicating the leading practices of innovation. In order to do so, we assessed the efficacy of an experiential exercise in relation to a traditional lecture. To prove out our hypothesis, we solicited undergraduate students attending the School of Business at George Mason University. Importantly, these students had not previously been exposed to the concepts related to innovation management and new product development.

The data collection (after a pilot where 24 students participated) was based on two parts. Part one was conducted immediately upon completion of the experiment and featured a Likert scaled 14 question surveys that captured the respondent’s feelings about attending this experiment (either lecture or experiential exercise). Part two of the data collection, designed to test for retention, required participants to return a week after the lecture or experiential exercise and answer a brief, 4 question survey.

A total of 152 respondents participated in the research study (80 attended lectures and 72 attended experiential exercises). The lecture was designed to last 90 minutes and the primary focus was to introduce the students to four leading practices of innovation. These concepts were taught through more “traditional” forms of learning including lecture, examples of the concepts in practice (using well known branded products) and interactive dialogue between the instructor and the students. The experiential exercise, also designed to last 90 minutes, involved six short (fictional) cases that required teams of 4-5 to make decisions relating to the management of a portfolio of innovative concepts.  While a very brief introduction to the four leading practices was provided to the students participating in the experiential exercise, the majority of time was spent on decision making and game play.

The combined results across the four retention questions show that when it comes to recall of the leading practices related to innovation conveyed to students the previous week, the mean score of recall by students in the experiential exercise group was far superior as compared to the lecture group. In addition, the T-Test scores highlight that average scores by the experiential group were far greater than the lecture group (with confidence interval exceeding 95%) for each of the 4 questions. Having successfully proven our hypothesis allows us to communicate on a different level to the organizations we desire to serve. Our research provides a powerful affirmation of what we have intuited all along – companies and organizations have an incredible opportunity to increase awareness of the leading practices of innovation by designing customized exercises which will prove far more effective than the tools they have historically relied on. More specifically, we can now better assist the numerous companies who have voiced the following challenges to us:

  • Employees and stakeholders are often reluctant to learn about the leading practices of innovation
  • For those employees and stakeholders open to learning, executives require better tools and techniques for conveying the leading practices of innovation in order to improve understanding and retention of these practices and ultimately, better adoption of these practices within the firm
